Finema

Trusted Timestamping Part 1: Scenarios

Evidentiary value is an essential component of important transactions. When a transaction is recorded in a printed document, one way to impart evidentiary value is by including date and time. You would already do that for a lot of other reasons. Date and time help you date documents for reference, organize information in a chronological order, and archive records in a way that retrieval is accessi

Evidentiary value is an essential component of important transactions. When a transaction is recorded in a printed document, one way to impart evidentiary value is by including date and time. You would already do that for a lot of other reasons. Date and time help you date documents for reference, organize information in a chronological order, and archive records in a way that retrieval is accessible and convenient. But most importantly, in the business context, date and time form part of what makes a contract legally binding.

And you would want to make sure that their inclusion, i.e. timestamping, is done in a trusted manner.

Published by WNEP Web Staff from www.wnep.com

In today‚Äôs world, technological advancement influences our lives in many ways, one of which is causing the adoption rate of electronic means of transactions to increase every year. Documents transform from a physical to digital form. For digital documents, the need for evidentiary value remains essential. We timestamp our digital files with date and time from, for example, our digital device‚Äôs clock.

However, it is important to take into consideration that digital documents must have equal value as their physical equivalents. Electronic signatures must be implemented in certain ways for them to be trustworthy. Likewise, simple timestamping may not be enough. Trusted timestamping with a reliable time source is needed.

Get to know timestamping

An electronic timestamp gives documents digital proof that they have not been modified from the moment of its application. [2] The concept has been around for quite some time and is being used in multiple industries. Timestamping enables organizations to record when a digital item‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsuch as a message, document, transaction or piece of software‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwas signed.[3]

In a legal setting, the existence of a timestamp associated with, say, an electronic signature, may not enough. To say that the document was signed when it was actually signed, you have to also prove that the timestamp of the signature is valid. This is where trusted timestamping comes in. Trusted timestamps are generated by a trusted third party that ensures that the they are not subject to manipulation by a local user. [4]

To be trusted, a timestamp is implemented in the form of so-called timestamp token. Associating a timestamp token with the document provides proof that the time stated is reliable. A timestamp token is a set of data that contains:

A date and time A hash digest of the document at hand An identifier of that which produces the timestamp token

Our usage of the phrase ‚Äòtrusted timestamp/timestamping‚Äô is taken from the standard ANSI X9.95. More about the process can be found in Timestamping Part 2: Process and Safeguards. But before delving into that, let‚Äôs consider a few increasingly complex scenarios.

When to timestamp

Imagine listing every decision you made each day. That would be impractical and exhausting. Same with timestamping, you don‚Äôt need to timestamp every transaction you do online each day. According to GlobalSign, there are two main reasons for including a trusted timestamp when you digitally sign a document‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääensuring long-term validation of the signature and adding non-repudiation or confidence around when the signature was actually applied.[4]

In many cases, timestamping is just a tool for you to keep track or serve as a record of transactions you do online. On the other hand, timestamping would be necessary when making a legal agreement with another organization or an important contract.

In this article, we will take you through different scenarios, from a physical timestamping use case to a trusted digital one, which will give you ideas of how trusted timestamping could add integrity to your document.

Scenario 0: Timestamping the inky way

By inserting date and time when a document was created, we can establish the timeline of when what took place. For example, at school, teachers make students write down their names and the date on the exam papers to help track the grading progress. Students write down the date of submission on their homework to indicate that their submissions are not late. It is even legislated in some jurisdictions that official documents shall include a timestamp.

Scenario 1: Timestamping the easy way

One easiest way someone would do digital timestamping is to have proof of existence with a time source. A convenient way to do this is with pictures. The time source could be anything ranging from a clock on the wall, the time on your computer screen, or a printed publication.

For example, you have an important meeting today. In order to attend, other attendees need to be sure that you are COVID-free. You want to send proof that your ATK result is obtained at the moment shortly before the meeting. That proof could be a photo of the ATK strip taken with a reliable time source, such as a smartphone, assuming that its time couldn‚Äôt or wouldn‚Äôt be modified.

Photo taken to timestamp the ATK COVID-19 test result

Of course, the assumptions hinge upon your technical illiteracy (i.e., you don‚Äôt know how to disconnect the phone from the time server) or your honesty. Either way, the timestamping is par for the course.

Scenario 2: Timestamping the newsy way

Instead of your phone, you could use a newspaper as a time source.

Courtesy of @marcklee and @anniespratt on Unsplash

This guarantees that something (e.g. the ATK strip in this case) existed or happened at a certain point in time, no later than that point onwards. Why? Because if the newspaper is dated 20 January 2020, presumably it didn‚Äôt exist before that. However, you could‚Äôve taken a selfie with it at any later date.

The verifier in Scenario 2 could at least believe this much without taking your honesty into account Scenario 3: Timestamping the naive way

The above approach wouldn‚Äôt be useful if the object being timestamped must be guaranteed to exist before a certain point in time. For example, if you have to sign some agreement no later than a week ago, a photo of the signed document with a newspaper from a week ago couldn‚Äôt rule out the possibility that you in fact might have signed it just yesterday.

Before going further into a new example, let‚Äôs look at how electronic signature works.

A simplified flow of electronic signature

The user uses their private key to cryptographically sign an electronic document. The certificate authority (CA) checks if the user is really who they claim to be, and issues a certificate that cryptographically links them to their public key, thereby assuring the signature was done by the rightful person.

Note that that the certificate issued by the CA has an expiry date, but it has nothing to do with the signing process. Suppose that the signing date is 15 Mar 2022 and the expiry date is 31 Dec 2022.

The same flow, with dates added

After 31 Dec 2022, there is no possible way to confirm whether or not the signature was signed before the expiry date. The signer could still use their private key to sign the document on, say, 2 Jan 2023 and tamper with the signing device‚Äôs clock in such a way that the signature date is recorded as 15 Mar 2022, before certificate expiry.

After certificate expiry, the verifier has a hard time trusting the signature.

Here‚Äôs timestamping the naive way: a trusted third party (TTP) could countersign the document before certificate expiry and add a little message‚Äîor, well, stamp‚Äîsaying their countersignature is given on 15 Mar 2022.

Scenario 3: using trusted third party to timestamp your signature

Now, after 31 Dec 2022, the verifier can believe that the signature was truly given on 15 Mar 2022, assuming that we can trust the TTP.

After certificate expiry, the verifier can trust the signature as long as they trust the TTP.

Now we can trust the TTP‚Äôs date. To what extent can we trust the TTP‚Äôs time?

You are almost done with the basic concepts of timestamping. Still you shouldn‚Äôt be too confident with the time proclaimed by the TTP until you are certain that the clock the TTP used to indicate his countersignature time is reliable. The TTP should periodically sync its clock to a trusted time source (‚Äòtiming centre‚Äô).

The TTP makes sure their clock is accurate by keeping it in sync with a timing centre. Scenario 4: Timestamping the proper way

How do you make sure the TTP can‚Äôt read your signed document?

So far, the TTP seems to have all access to the information written in the documents since it has to counter-sign them. What happens to privacy? Is there a privacy-preserving approach? To keep your content safe from prying eyes, we could hash the document into a digest. Hashing is simply a process of applying a cryptographic hash function to transform the data of your document into a meaningless string of characters.

Instead of countersigning the whole document, the TTP signs just the hash.

The TTP is what is known as a timestamp authority (TSA). In practice, there are many schemes where the timing centre and the TSA influences each other. For more information, see ITU-R TF.1876 Standard: Trusted time source for Time Stamp Authority.

The industry-standard name of the signed digest is a timestamp token, and the final package is basically a timestamped and signed document. Below is a complete overview of the process of creating a signed document with trusted timestamping where each node is labelled with a proper name.

An overview of how one timestamps a signed document

This scenario features a signed document as an object being timestamped. In general, you can send the hash of any electronic document to the TSA.

In conclusion, simple timestamping may not be sufficient considering today‚Äôs technology and the level of assurance required. You need a package of data structure called a timestamping token provided by a timestamping authority (TSA). Trusted timestamping adds integrity and evidentiary value to the document.

More on timestamping in Trusted Timestamping Part 2: Introduction and Timestamping Part 3: Family of Standards.

Trusted Timestamping Part 1: Scenarios was originally published in Finema on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

04:02 • 3 days ago

Tuesday, 29. March 2022

Continuum Loop Inc.

Worried About Digital Identity?

The post Worried About Digital Identity? appeared first on Continuum Loop Inc..

Continuum Loop Worried About Digital Identity? The Security of Our Identities

by Christine Martin

 

One of the critical elements of implementing a digital id system is its wide adoption by the general public. Still, from my research in the world of decentralized identity, I see that the general public is hesitant to adopt, which made me want to offer reassurance. I‚Äôm deep into digital id, working closely with one of the world‚Äôs leading experts. I acknowledge the potential issues, but I also see significant benefits. I‚Äôm part of international working groups developing digital id guidelines and frameworks. I know that organizations and people like me are working to protect us. 

I decided to take to Reddit and ask about digital identity concerns. I‚Äôm not a heavy Reddit user; I only joined in January, so I don‚Äôt typically get much attention, but I couldn‚Äôt have asked for a better reply to my first Reddit post. I knew I could answer it and hopefully ease some concerns.

If you are worried about the security of your identity, you would want to adopt a digital id; it can also be called self-sovereign or decentralized identity, but I‚Äôll stick with digital id here.

The most basic explanation I can offer is that separate packets of verifiable credentials will be encrypted on your device, and these will make up your digital id. It will be like carrying around the entire contents of your physical wallet but securely encrypted. Offering your credentials will be verified via biometrics, similar to how your apple pay wallet works upon each use.

If you‚Äôre thinking about backup and recovery, please don‚Äôt at this point. Let‚Äôs try to understand digital identity first. I will cover the backup and recovery in another post. 

If you are keen and don‚Äôt want to wait, check out Chapter 9.7 of Self-Sovereign Identity for a detailed overview of Backup and Recovery.

Your Identity is Compromised

 

You can download and install an app called REVOKE, where you enter your email and see how often your data has been subject to breaches. You will likely find out that your information has been subject to a data breach, and you didn‚Äôt even know about it. Companies like Bell Canada, HauteLook and MyFitnessPal are just a few that were compromised where my personal information was subject to a data breach. These companies can‚Äôt guarantee to keep your information safe. Facebook and Google have been subject to breaches, and every other website where you create a user-id holds your data online somewhere. You don‚Äôt own, hold or control your data. 

We need to take back accountability for our data. It‚Äôs not up to Facebook or Google; they‚Äôre not security companies. These organizations do us a favour by offering backup and recovery options, but we pay the price. Furthermore, they are claiming your data as their asset and making money.

 

Government Involvement

 

After several rounds of consultations, the Ontario government will launch its digital id system this fall. Continuum Loop was heavily involved in these consultations, and we‚Äôre happy to see them come to fruition. We believe the Ontario government has been proactive in taking the necessary steps to implement an ethical digital identity system for all Ontarians.

Let‚Äôs look at the Ontario Government program.

Notice that ‚ÄúNOT stored in a central database‚Äù point. This is good because hackers are more tempted by large lists that they can hit. Imagine getting a list of every Ontario resident ‚Äì that‚Äôs attractive to hackers. Instead, your credentials exist only on your phone, protected by your phone‚Äôs security and more. Now a hacker has to attack every phone to get the complete list. That‚Äôs hard to scale ‚Äì and would take forever. More on that below‚Ä¶

The government‚Äôs involvement in digital id will be issuing verifiable digital credentials of the physical ones we already have. The government issues your Drivers License, Social Insurance Number, Birth Certificate etc. everything is already in their hands. The digital id will allow you to validate your id without sharing unnecessary information, like proving that you are over 18 without showing your actual birthdate. It‚Äôs that simple.

Digital id is not about the government taking control of your id or holding your credentials; it‚Äôs about taking back control. It‚Äôs about offering your data in a verifiable credential format that you will store and manage on your device. The whole concept of digital id revolves around increased security and holder accountability. You get to own, hold, and control your own identity.  

 

Blockchain Technology and Framework

 

I can choose to attack an organization for millions of records or do it one by one ‚Äì which is more challenging? And if I do it one by one, how do I know the credential I crack will hold any value? Watch this short video explaining Distributed Ledger (Blockchain) Technology; I couldn‚Äôt explain it better. The very nature of this technology makes them immune to cyber-crimes since all the copies stored across the network would need to be attacked simultaneously for the attack to be successful. A hacker would have to 1. Get into your digital wallet, verify via biometrics and then 2. Crack a random credential and hope it has any value. How does the hacker even choose a valuable target? Blockchain technology makes it not worth it for the hackers anymore.

Steps are being taken all around the globe to implement digital id systems that will work in harmony with each other and be beneficial for all, no matter your geolocation. The ID2020 alliance is spearheading this effort. They are a global coalition of public and private sectors working to provide an identity platform for all. This identity platform will be based on blockchain technology and allow for secure, verified digital identities. This framework will make it easier for people to travel and do business worldwide and make essential digital services more accessible. These systems are being developed and modelled to meet the eIDAS regulatory framework. This framework seeks to harmonize digital identity and trust services in the European economic area while helping businesses, citizens, and authorities carry out secure and seamless electronic interactions.

 

Take Back Control

 

How many times have you scanned and emailed your driver‚Äôs license as proof of identification? That is neither convenient nor secure. Where does that copy of your driver‚Äôs licence end up within the organization? Did the recipient file it away in a locked cabinet? Was it saved on their computer? Did they need to know everything about you ‚Äì your license number, height, weight, eye colour, etc. ‚Äì or did they just need to know you were over a certain age? Digital identity will cut this out. You can instantly prove who you are without scanning or emailing anything. Just tap the ‚Äúok‚Äù button on your screen. That organization only gets the information they need, nothing else, nothing more. You won‚Äôt have to worry about your information being shared within the organization by unauthorized employees or subject to breaches. 

In a world where our data is bought and sold without our consent, it‚Äôs more important than ever to control our identities. It‚Äôs time to take back control while becoming personally accountable for its security and recovery. We can protect our identities from theft and fraud, ensuring that our personal information is safe and secure. With a digital identity, you‚Äôll be able to rest assured that your data is safe and sound. It‚Äôs up to you. 

Visit our blog to learn more about decentralized identity, and subscribe to our newsletter for updates.

Join the SSI Crew!

The first step on your journey to understanding Decentralized Identity and taking control of your own digital world.

You're in the Crew!

Name

Email

Subscribe

Follow Follow Follow

The post Worried About Digital Identity? appeared first on Continuum Loop Inc..

Analyst Chat #118: A first look at the new Trans-Atlantic Data Privacy Framework

On March 25th, 2022 the European Commission and the US government announced a new agreement governing the transfer of data between the EU and the US. Mike Small and Annie Bailey join Matthias to have a first look as analysts (not lawyers) at this potential milestone for data privacy between the European and the US regions.

On March 25th, 2022 the European Commission and the US government announced a new agreement governing the transfer of data between the EU and the US. Mike Small and Annie Bailey join Matthias to have a first look as analysts (not lawyers) at this potential milestone for data privacy between the European and the US regions.



22:00 • 4 days ago

Jolocom

Decentralization is the Future of Digitization

What we will explore? To begin with, the article states that digitization has accelerated immensely due to Covid and predicts that this will stay beyond the pandemic. In the first part, a light is being shed on the challenges that this brings, stating that some breaking points can be eased with more digitization rather than ... [:en]The post Decentralization is the Future of Digitization appeare
What we will explore?

To begin with, the article states that digitization has accelerated immensely due to Covid and predicts that this will stay beyond the pandemic. In the first part, a light is being shed on the challenges that this brings, stating that some breaking points can be eased with more digitization rather than less. This is further analysed in the second part, examining how effective digitization can be achieved. Decentralized technology is mentioned as one solution to trust challenges. Next, the article offers an outlook of a sustainable, future-proof solution. Digital identity data is introduced as having a positive impact on Germany‚Äôs future as well as Europe‚Äôs. Following, benefits of a decentralized identity based on a fully open infrastructure are given.  Lastly, the article closes off with naming ten potential use cases, such as digital money, eGovernment or HealthTech. 

Digitization is now more relevant than ever

‚ÄòThe spread of COVID-19 and the government measures taken to respond to it have turned our previous lives upside down and revealed where the breaking points are.‚Äô

The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated digitization. That is the consensus among many experts around the globe ‚Äì including the OECD, ‚Äúthe world moved online,‚Äù McKinsey, ‚ÄúIn just a few months‚Äô‚Ä¶ the COVID-19 crisis has brought about years of change,‚Äù and Deutsche Telekom, ‚Äúthe pandemic has developed from an unwanted stress test to an accelerator of digitization in all areas of life.‚Äù

The spread of COVID-19 and the government measures taken to respond to it have turned our previous lives upside down and revealed where the breaking points are. Commerce, education, public administration, the health sector, as well as everyday office work ‚Äì little of this was digitized as effectively as we‚Äôve come to expect in other parts of our lives. This in turn exacerbated the severity of the COVID-19 pandemic to an unnecessary degree, as seen in the fact that sectors or organizations that were more thoroughly digitized were able to react to the pandemic more flexibly. These were the bodies that weathered the new constraints and dynamics more quickly and easily than those where digitization needed to be improved or was just beginning.  What‚Äôs more, it appears that things will stay this way beyond the pandemic.

Alongside the COVID-19 pandemic and its repercussions on our everyday life, we are starting to see and feel the economic effects and aftermath. If investments can be sourced, then they are most likely to flow into digitization, as noted by the likes of Forbes, Morgan Stanley and finance.swiss. Their number one purpose: profiting from the advancement of digitization projects, one of the few sectors of the economy actually thriving within the crisis. Digital identities will be the next linchpin of an inclusive economic growth around the world. ‚ÄúExtending full digital ID coverage could unlock economic value equivalent to 3 to 13 percent of GDP in 2030‚Äîin developed economies and will penetrate even faster in emergent nations, says McKinsey in their Digital Identification report. 

Why are there delays in digitization? ‚ÄòHaving shared our data with countless entities online, we have little control over our own data once uploaded.‚Äô

Digitization does not solve every problem. Indeed it will also create its own challenges to security and trust within society. However, some of the exposed breaking points can be eased, repaired or even prevented by more digitization rather than less. Digital representations like your driver‚Äôs license, passport or vaccination certificate will make everyone‚Äôs lives much easier.

Identifying the problem

Navigating the Internet requires an exchange of information. As such, various levels of trust and security are desirable and often mandatory. Currently, our online interactions happen through independent platforms that apply their own specific architectures to solve these prerequisites. However, as few people want to rely on a single platform, we end up sharing our data with countless online entities. Having done this, we have little control over our own data once uploaded. What‚Äôs more,  we now have so many online interactions that it can be impossible to keep track of all these interactions or with whom our data has been shared. 

Secondly, access and security are extremely poor. No platform can claim to be 100 percent secure against the leaking of users‚Äô private data, be it by accident, security gaps or malicious attacks. The current username/password access to online services is not only a usability nightmare, but also an opportunity for impersonation and fraud. Recently added two factor authentication is a measure to improve the situation, but still far from the standard level of security that should be deemed acceptable.

The third factor is that we remain a mostly analogue world, especially when it comes to documents that earn their trustworthiness through the issuing authority. A passport issued by a country, an educational credential diploma issued by a school or university, a referral issued by a previous employer, and so on. Even payment is still mostly analogue, with online shops requiring you to manually add your credit card information or IBAN.

What might a sustainable, future-proof solution look like? no single points of failure individual, fine grain control of data and identity infrastructure that can not be controlled or dominated by one or a few large players ( e.g. the way the Bitcoin system has evolved, Facebook for social networking, or Google for Ads and everything else) systems that are trustworthy by virtue of their open, auditable and extensible nature Systems that model sharing of control and power among the connected users and insitutions Systems where trust dynamics are transparently defined and collectively understood (unlike e.g. Facebook, where you have no idea how they are monitizing your data or manipulating the information you consume) Minimal to no costs to participate

Digital identity data that can be exchanged in a way that‚Äôs secure, reliable, scalable and convenient. This would have a positive impact on the economic future of Germany, Europe and the whole world, while at the same time enhancing the privacy of the individual. And to be a success, an ecosystem of verified digital identities must 

be usable by any organization across any sector,  be interoperable, following open standards and schema, be usable by any individual without exemption, be secure and privacy preserving, be human-centric, enabling data sovereignty, be compliant, applicable to any regulatory environment, be usable in regulated contexts and recognised by both public and private organizations, be acceptable worldwide.

Among the many ways digital identities could be used across a wide range of industries include know your customer and anti money laundering compliance (KYC and AML) requirements for financial institutions, digital payments, single sign-on (SSO), proof of age, loyalty cards, official documents (such as passports and national ID cards), diplomas and more.

Fortunately, over the last few years a small industry working on self-sovereign identity (SSI) has emerged, with a solution that delivers these requirements.

How do we achieve an effectively digitized future?

Collectively, we refer to technologies and systems that meet the above criteria as ‚Äúdecentralized‚Äù, in that they are not proprietarily controlled or asymmetrically designed to disempower or manipulate some or all of the stakeholders in the system.

‚ÄòIn the light of this, decentralized technology in general and decentralized identity management in particular have become of utmost importance and interest.‚Äô

It is our belief that future-proof technologies can only be developed in partnership. Especially when it comes to Web 3.0 infrastructure and digital identities, a decentralized, open-source approach is essential to secure the Internet as a democratic global infrastructure. Core areas of this global infrastructure should be seen as public services and operated in a way that ensures their accessibility and value for the whole population and economy. Decentralized technologies based on open standards will be essential for enabling cooperation at eye level in the national and, above all, international sphere.

Privacy by design and decentralization are concepts that promise us better solutions, but the pressure of time makes it all too tempting to take the quick and dirty approach. In Germany, for example, the federal government initially decided to store data from the nation‚Äôs Corona-Warn app on centralized servers, as reported by Reuters in April 2020. In response, multiple stakeholders like the Chaos Computer Club (CCC) loudly criticized the plans and the resulting public outcry forced the government to reconsider. The fact that the government heard the criticisms, re-evaluated its proposals and opted for a decentralized version of its Corona app instead ‚Äì one  where data will only be stored on users‚Äô phones instead of centralized government servers ‚Äì was news well received by large parts of society. Talking to TechCrunch, decentralization campaigners of the the DP-3T project said, ‚ÄúDP-3T is very happy to see that Germany is adopting a decentralized approach to contact tracing.‚Äù

In the light of this, decentralized technology in general and decentralized identity management in particular have become of utmost importance and interest. The primary assumption is that centralized services create a level of control and insight into a citizens‚Äô life that would significantly violate privacy (hence the need for GDPR) and also fail to provide an adequate level of security. Data leaks, breaches and cloning are just some of the problems faced on a regular basis, as this report from Deutsche Welle confirms. 

So what makes a digital identity?

The range of digital identities is broad. They can be limited to a simple combination of username/password (Web 2.0). They can be public/private keypairs (Web 3.0) with no reference to personal credentials. Or they can be linked to personally identifiable information drawn from official proof, such as an ID document. They can also include more detailed information, such as payment data, health information or evidence of training and employment.

A verifiable digital identity records data that contains the identity and, where applicable, other identity credentials (such as whether the bearer holds a diploma issued by a university and/or has a driver‚Äôs licence issued by a national authority) about a natural person or legal entity which have been issued or attested by one or more trusted sources, such as a bank.

Bringing these pieces of information together to paint a comprehensive picture of the respective person or entity requires a high degree of integrity and trust throughout the entire network.

However, the single sign-on authentication schemes offered by tech companies do not currently guarantee that the data entered by the customer is actually correct. In regulated sectors, such as banking or mobile telecommunications, companies are legally obliged to verify their customers‚Äô data. Though they do so conscientiously, legally valid identification can often only be carried out with a break in the media chain (e.g. video identification or the German Post-Ident service.). And, in Germany, the electronic ID (eID) function of national ID cards has not been sufficiently accepted by consumers. 

Centralized Identity vs SSI Putting people in control with SSI IssueCentralized IdentitySelf-sovereign Identityidentitycontrolled by identity providercan be withdrawn by third partyfragmented across platformscontrolled by individuaIportable across networksreusable across organizationsdatafragmented access across platformscontrolled by third party organizationscannot delete datafull exposuretrackableportable across platformsuser centric control from an individual‚Äôs digital walletcan delete dataselective exposuresecurityusername and password dilemmaplatforms are honeypots for hackersprivate-public key infrastructureencryptedlimited data exposure The benefits of a decentralized identity based on a fully open infrastructure include: users having full control over access to their identity data, through a facility such as an ID wallet on their smartphone, identity data being transferable via standardized data formats, schemes and protocols, decentralised data storage protecting against attacks and central system failures, data of identity subjects being non-correlatable, thus protecting privacy, Infrastructure based on open standards guaranteeing all citizens equal opportunities, participation, growth and inclusion, data minimisation, ensuring identity attributes are only transferred if necessary. What are the potential use cases?

Already, we can identify and address a number of use cases where decentralized identity could accelerate and scale digitization to a level that benefits the most. What‚Äôs more, these use cases may also show how decentralized identity provides a significantly higher level of security and trust, not only for citizens but also for the governments and organizations that adopt it.

To paint a better picture, here are some of the use cases that have arisen during the COVID-19 pandemic.

1. EduTech becomes essential

The crisis has been a wake-up call for the education sector. Teachers are still trying to figure out how video conferencing tools can be best used to communicate effectively with their students. Many companies are positioning themselves as the best solution for digital education, but most rely on centralized web technology.

Yet truly secure processes, ranging from registration for schools and universities to participation in exams online or issuance of digital diplomas that require secure authentication, are still rarely in place.

2. HealthTech makes its big appearance

The innovation industry should have the right digital products for the health industry already. It should be offering reliable solutions for everything from infection tracking and telemedical calls, to family doctor services, rapid testing and development of vaccines. But it is not. 

For many reasons, development and approval has been expensive and lengthy, and data protection has put a brake on the research benefits of shared health data in particular. Citizens, insurance companies, doctors, hospitals and governmental authorities are expected to now be more willing to drive digitization in the sector.

Patients could carry their health data with them at all times; including treatment history, x-rays, laboratory results and prescribed medication, as well as insurance data. In turn, doctors would gain instant access to medical records, make speedier diagnoses and be able to verify the health information they‚Äôre given about their patients.

A solution to connect 3. Remote work spreads 

Home working has gained much wider acceptance, with it frequently benefiting both employer and employee. Wherever physical presence is not a necessity, people are currently expected to spend more of their working time from home. For this to be properly effective, it will require innovation for both parties. Employers and employees will need the appropriate digital tools for remote work to access company information and online services seamlessly. This access needs to be fully customizable, adjustable and, of course, secure.

4. Faster, easier eCommerce for local retailers

Small businesses can no longer ignore the need for an online presence. The pandemic has accelerated take-up and innovation. Consumers expect to be able to order nearly everything online, be it pasta from the restaurant around the corner, virtual classes in anything from ballet to baking or delivery of pretty much any physical good you can think of. This clearly shows where we are heading. Accordingly, the demand for online shop solutions that anyone can use easily, customer and service provider alike, is vital.

Existing platforms, such as Amazon, are booming, but their monopoly positions are unhealthy and micro transactions rarely viable. Local solutions are required to supply everything a micro retailer needs (eg. order system, payment processing, delivery status messaging service and so on).  

When individuals have accounts in the shape of their digital identities that are reusable for the widest range of transactions, both consumers and micro service providers will benefit.

5. Efficient job placement

Record unemployment in Europe and the world will shape a new future for job platforms. This is less likely to be in how  companies look for skilled workers, more how jobseekers offer their services. Digital tools that help individuals document their diplomas and certificates, as well as attestations from previous employers, will be needed. Conversely, companies will require an efficient way to verify the authenticity of applicants‚Äô documents.

Jobseekers could carry their employment history, qualifications, diplomas and references with them at all times.  Potential employers would then be able to instantly access and verify the trusted information of applicants.

6. Good cyber security is becoming a must

Cyber attacks have increased worldwide, particularly following the switch to home working. Remote work requires secure authentication to defend against attacks when data flows between the homes of the employees and company clouds, for example. Besides the increasing digitization of existing online services, there will be additional relocation in many areas (trade, education, health, government, etc) to a better decentralized infrastructure which provides improved flexibility and security. Centralized systems are not suitable ‚Äì they represent honeypots for hackers. Decentralized technology paired with strong encryption, however, can provide the security and trust required.

7. Digital entertainment explosion

Immediate winners during the crisis include not only video conferencing and collaboration tools, but also video streaming platforms and chat services. And the great retreat into homes may not be as temporary as first thought. It‚Äôs quite possible that digital social interactions will become the 21st Century standard. The focus on small family units will create time at home that needs to be filled, with streaming videos being a case in point with big Internet companies already working to increase the rollout of the next generation gaming and eSports platforms. This will require privacy controls and, to protect minors, the ability to determine age accurately.

8. More efficient eGovernment

The performance of many eGovernment solutions remain far from where they could or even should be. There is much room for improvement in digitization within authorities and the public sector as a whole. At present, only a few Baltic and Nordic countries can claim to have such services as the ‚Äúonce-only-principal‚Äù in place where citizens and companies only have to provide certain standard information to the authorities and administrations once. However, these are highly centralized and only work because of a pre-existing culture of trust that can‚Äôt be assumed elsewhere. Here, again, decentralized technology paired with encryption can create the security and trust required.

9. Travel Documents that meet all needs

We exist in a world of constantly changing travel constraints and cross border requirements ‚Äì who can travel where, tracking where travellers have previously been, proof of vaccination, verifiable test results. With decentralized technology, all travel documents can be verified securely, more quickly and more reliably than with current paper versions or centralized databases.

10. Digital money for all

Even before the crisis, hard cash was becoming less welcome in many countries. Now, cashless payment has become the standard in an increasing number of outlets. At the same time, banks‚Äô projects to create central bank-based digital currencies (CBDCs) using blockchain technology are progressing. A test program for a state digital currency started in South Korea in April 2021. The EU has announced the introduction of a digital Euro within the next few years. Decentralized digitization of money will enable cashless transactions for everyone, replacing the expensive and often cumbersome online payment solutions in current use.

Conclusion

All in all, recent developments underline the trend of digitization in almost all spheres of life, be it public or private. With this in mind, it makes sense to increasingly focus on digital privacy and how to protect and strengthen an individual‚Äôs identity online, while also keeping up to date with the fast developing digitization. The continuing Covid crisis, once more, offers an opportunity to implement decentralization in a trustworthy way. This article hopes to have shed a light on the significance of this step, as digital privacy and data sovereignty might quickly become neglected when digitization takes up its speed. 

[:en]The post Decentralization is the Future of Digitization appeared first on Jolocom.[:]

19:46 • 4 days ago

Finicity

Finicity and Fiserv Offer More Consumer Choice Through Secure Data Access

Finicity, a Mastercard company, and Fiserv, Inc., both leaders in open banking technology, are advancing the future of open finance through secure data sharing. A data access agreement between the companies will allow thousands of Fiserv financial institution clients to enable consumers to provide clear and explicit permission to securely share their account information with [‚Ä¶] The post Finicit

Finicity, a Mastercard company, and Fiserv, Inc., both leaders in open banking technology, are advancing the future of open finance through secure data sharing. A data access agreement between the companies will allow thousands of Fiserv financial institution clients to enable consumers to provide clear and explicit permission to securely share their account information with apps that use Finicity‚Äôs open banking platform.

‚ÄúThis data access agreement complements Mastercard‚Äôs longstanding partnership with Fiserv, demonstrated by our aligned missions to empower consumers and organizations to permission the use of their financial data for their benefit,‚Äù said Ryan Christiansen, SVP, Data Access Partnerships at Mastercard. ‚ÄúThe strong payments connectivity between Mastercard and Fiserv via tokenization, traditional processing and beyond extends across infrastructure, applications and services to the secure and highly reliable API connections we‚Äôre enabling through open banking.‚Äù

Finicity is a leader in signed data access agreements. Through this partnership with Fiserv, a major core banking solution provider, Mastercard connectivity continues to outpace competitors and further diminishes credential use within the ecosystem.

Read more here.

The post Finicity and Fiserv Offer More Consumer Choice Through Secure Data Access appeared first on Finicity.

Elliptic

Elliptic Traces $540 Million Stolen From the Ronin DeFi Bridge

The Ronin Network has announced that 173,600 ETH and 25.5 million USD Coins were stolen from the Ronin cross-chain bridge on March 23rd. The total value of the stolen cryptoassets at the time of the theft was $540 million ‚Äì making it the second largest crypto theft of all time. 

The Ronin Network has announced that 173,600 ETH and 25.5 million USD Coins were stolen from the Ronin cross-chain bridge on March 23rd. The total value of the stolen cryptoassets at the time of the theft was $540 million ‚Äì making it the second largest crypto theft of all time. 

19:26 • 4 days ago

Civic

A Technical Q&A With Snowcrash About Partnering With Civic

A conversation with Tamay Aykut, VP of Engineering at Snowcrash, and Dan Kelleher, VP of Engineering at Civic. Civic Can you tell us a bit about the Snowcrash platform? Snowcrash  Absolutely! Snowcrash is a platform for non-fungible digital goods and social tokens, which we all know as NFTs, that is built on the Solana blockchain. [‚Ä¶] The post A Technical Q&A With Snowcrash About Partne

A conversation with Tamay Aykut, VP of Engineering at Snowcrash, and Dan Kelleher, VP of Engineering at Civic.

Civic

Can you tell us a bit about the Snowcrash platform?

Snowcrash 

Absolutely! Snowcrash is a platform for non-fungible digital goods and social tokens, which we all know as NFTs, that is built on the Solana blockchain. We work with major IP holders and brands, artists, generative scientists, and more to create collections of master and or limited editions, streaming rights and digital goods over a broad category of digital assets, which could be visual art, music, movies, sports, anything collectible, basically.

We recently announced the platform‚Äôs partnership with Sony Music and Universal Music Group and we like to think of the platform as the nexus of Wall Street, Hollywood, and Silicon Valley.

Our main goal is to offer a safe, intuitive, and frictionless experience to end users who want to own digital collectibles from world-class IP holders.

So, in short, we are a fully integrated premium digital platform, and a creative production studio, providing concepts, state of the art production facilities, marketing, minting, even sales services, with a strong engineering team. And, we‚Äôre excited to be partnering with Civic to help make the platform even more user-friendly.

Civic  

That‚Äôs an awesome description. Snowcrash has some really impressive partners.

Snowcrash

We agree! It‚Äôs very inspiring for us and we‚Äôre incredibly proud of the partnerships we‚Äôve been able to announce thus far. All of this just speaks to the incredible growth of the NFT market and the groundbreaking opportunities it offers to IP holders and artists to establish and control their digital legacy on the blockchain.

In a few years the landscape is going to be very different, and we‚Äôre laying the groundwork now because we believe in a bigger, more dynamic future for the NFT market. We‚Äôre doing what we can to be stewards to the big players, offering up a safe and intuitive experience for people outside of the crypto ecosystem to come in and realize the potential this new medium holds.

Civic 

When you initially started working with Civic, what were you trying to accomplish in relation to identity? What kind of problems were you looking to solve?

Snowcrash 

We think an incredibly important component of our platform is going to be good bot protection. Insofar as in the wider NFT marketplace, bots are a big problem for genuine fans and users to engage with platforms because bots undermine the fairness of NFT minting and drops.

Our mission is to bring existing and new IP into the world of NFTs and blockchain, and since we are dealing with very high-level content. It‚Äôs our duty to protect those digital assets as much as possible and provide a fair and safe marketplace to our customers ‚Äì which can be big organization brands, artists, but also those of the users, the fans who want to own the content produced by their favorite artists. So, our search for a solution that is secure, flexible and user friendly led us straight to Civic!

Civic 

That‚Äôs great. After you became acquainted with Civic‚Äôs bot protection, what appealed to you about how Civic handles digital identity?

Snowcrash 

We would first say that the Civic solution is very user friendly and scalable. We have assessed several solutions and ultimately, we found Civic‚Äôs solutions the most elegant. Outside of bot protection depending on the type of drop we also need certain know-your-client functionality. But we want this process to be as frictionless as possible for the end-user. We want to break down the barriers of entry, not make it annoying to get into the world of NFTs. Imagine you have to go through a verification process for every platform, and marketplace you want to engage with. In the worst case, you have to share all your details with different third parties over and over again. And that sounds horrible. Right? So that‚Äôs not something you want. That‚Äôs where Civic Pass really shines. You do the verification only once and then it‚Äôs on-chain. Once verified you have your ID token which is attached to your wallet, you can prove your identity across different marketplaces and platforms like ours. And we emphasize the importance and need of such a scalable solution.

Civic 

Now that you‚Äôve been working with Civic, what kind of experiences are you building for your users that these identity solutions help provide? Also, what features would you like to see in the near future?

Snowcrash 

Having those ID tokens integrated into our system allows us to have a frictionless and user-friendly experience both for the organizations, the artists, and also the consumers. That‚Äôs very important for us because some of the content is only meant to be accessed by the owner. 

This all just helps us to protect these assets from everyone‚Äôs perspective all at once. It‚Äôs like an elegant Web2 solution for Web3 ‚Äì this is what we‚Äôve all been imagining when we think about being able to onboard people into the Web3 space.

In the future, we think another nice feature would be on-chain whitelisting with ID tokens. Assuming that we will have our NFT membership tokens and other NFTs, they will have utilities, right? And they may be an entry to exclusive communities or give you access to other limited NFT additions. So, we would like to work on a solution that makes all this happen in an on-chain way.

Civic 

You mentioned that the user will only be expected to go through the ID verification process once. That is certainly one aspect where I think that it‚Äôs an example of doing things the right way rather than going to every separate organization, every separate portal, and providing the same information that gets transferred around multiple times. One of the other things we talk about is representing identity on-chain and sometimes that‚Äôs misunderstood as storing identity on chain, which obviously we don‚Äôt do. We store essentially a proxy or an avatar on-chain. And you, as the protocol, don‚Äôt need to know anything about the end user ‚Äì just that they‚Äôve gone through the checks that you require. And our thesis right now is that these checks are common. Nobody‚Äôs going around reinventing the wheel. 

There are obviously various multiple versions, but the number of special cases are outweighed by the number of common cases. So, this ties in with the idea that there‚Äôs true self-sovereignty in the ecosystem. An end-user shares their information only with the organizations they want to share with, and as few as possible. But then this proxy that you get on-chain is sufficient to unlock various products on-chain, who in principle don‚Äôt need to know anything about the user. They just need to know that they meet those requirements. Be those requirements, simple ones like ‚ÄúI am not a bot,‚Äù or slightly more complicated like ‚ÄúI am over 21,‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not living in a certain region.‚Äù These are the important things that users must be able to prove. But it‚Äôs important that they go through these verification steps as few times as possible. And that‚Äôs really the core of what we‚Äôre building and that is essentially what we‚Äôve released with the integration of Civic Pass on Snowcrash.

Civic

Let‚Äôs talk for a second about Web3 and its founding principles. It offers an ownership layer that essentially, gives power back to the user. What are the values that go into building an NFT platform like this and how are you translating the ethos of Web3 and blockchain, and even rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll and all of these rebellious ideas into this new technology?

Snowcrash 

Lovely question! We think one of the concepts that Web3 enables is the internet of value, right? So, an internet of everything, or anything of value from money to IP, can travel as fast as information itself. So how does it translate into the user experience that we are building? I think I want to cite one of our founders, Walter De Brouwer actually, who summed it up pretty nicely. In three simple terms. It‚Äôs collect, exhibit, and belong. 

So, number one, collect ‚Äì it all starts with a digital wallet and these wallets will be the browsers of the future, bringing users from Web 2.0 to Web3. And Snowcrash is providing a smooth and user-friendly integration of wallets functioning as frictionless on and off ramps, featuring, of course, a user friendly on-chain verification with Civic Pass to help everything begin!

Number two, exhibit. What you collect is who you are and how you want to represent yourself. This is essential to finding kindred spirits and likeminded people in this digital environment to truly form communities. With Snowcrash, you can display your NFTs on your media profile like one might utilize Twitter, Facebook, Discord, etc. Community building opportunities are limitless. 

And number three is belong. NFTs will become a social token and have certain utilities. There will be a lot of services coupled to them and adventures will be driven by these clubs, and even some competitions might start. So, the members will be proud to belong as well as allow you to leverage any privileges you have by being involved with these groups.

Civic 

Wonderful. Thank you so much, this has been a really fun chat! We are super excited to collaborate with Snowcrash and can‚Äôt wait to share more exciting news with our community as we continue down this road together!

Snowcrash

Thank you!

The post A Technical Q&A With Snowcrash About Partnering With Civic appeared first on Civic Technologies, Inc..

16:01 • 4 days ago

Civic Partners With Snowcrash for NFTs by Sony Music Entertainment and Universal Music Group

Civic‚Äôs identity verification technology will be leveraged by Snowcrash to prevent bots from participating in the NFT drops of illustrious musicians and artists.  SAN FRANCISCO and LOS ANGELES (March 29, 2022) ‚Äî Today, Civic, a leader in digital identity solutions for Web3, and Snowcrash, a premier NFT trading platform, announced a strategic partnership to create [‚Ä¶] The post Civic Partners

Civic‚Äôs identity verification technology will be leveraged by Snowcrash to prevent bots from participating in the NFT drops of illustrious musicians and artists. 

SAN FRANCISCO and LOS ANGELES (March 29, 2022) ‚Äî Today, Civic, a leader in digital identity solutions for Web3, and Snowcrash, a premier NFT trading platform, announced a strategic partnership to create permissioned access to the Snowcrash platform. Through this partnership, Snowcrash users will be checked for real person liveness and bots will be prevented from participating in the NFT drops of acclaimed musicians, artists, and other creators. Snowcrash recently launched its NFT trading platform with partners Sony Music Entertainment and Universal Music Group with the aim of providing NFT content for cultural icons, including Bob Dylan and Miles Davis.

Bots have flooded NFT mints on the Solana blockchain since the summer of 2021, when the NFT ecosystem proliferated on the chain. The bots have a simple but destructive agenda: to scoop up inventory and flip the NFTs on secondary markets, a practice that is profitable for fraudsters but harmful for nascent NFT artists and communities. Since the recent introduction of the company‚Äôs Civic Pass product into the ecosystem, Civic has protected more than 200 mints, helped nearly 100,000 buyers successfully mint NFTs, and blocked a staggering 900,000+ bots from attempting purchases. Snowcrash will leverage Civic Pass, an on-chain solution that both restricts access from bots and protects user privacy at the same time. This will protect the NFT content of the storied musicians and artists of Snowcrash. 

Jesse Dylan, Founder of Snowcrash, shared, ‚ÄúWe are incredibly pleased to partner with Civic to protect our fans, artists, and communities. Through a practice similar to ticket scalping, botting has plagued NFT mints. Civic elegantly resolves this issue for us by identifying human participants and prohibiting bot participation, giving our NFT partners and IP holders like Sony Music Entertainment and Universal Music Group peace of mind.‚Äù 

Chris Hart, CEO of Civic, said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre delighted to partner with Snowcrash, a company that shares our core belief that opportunities to participate in Web3 should be accessible to everyone. We‚Äôre so excited for high-caliber companies like Snowcrash to up-level the NFT ecosystem and help more people gain access to this cultural moment in time.‚Äù 

Walter De Brouwer, Founder of Snowcrash added, ‚ÄúPartnering with projects like Civic that prioritize the user experience is extremely important as we continue to establish Snowcrash as the premier marketplace for world-class IP holders to launch their treasured properties into the world of NFTs.‚Äù

The Civic and Snowcrash partnership offers top-tier brands access to a growing market for their digital collectibles on the Solana blockchain, while helping to define Web3 identity standards in the process.   

About Civic

Civic is a leading provider of identity management tools for web3, empowering people to easily and privately manage their identities across chains with an on-chain representation of their reusable identity. The company‚Äôs flagship product, Civic Pass, is an integrated permissioning tool that helps business customers enable secure access to their on-chain assets. Users may also manage their Web3 identity, presence and reputation with a dashboard. Civic aims to be the most trusted on-chain Web3 identity tool in the world, used by billions every day. Civic was co-founded in 2015 by Vinny Lingham and Jonathan Smith.

About Snowcrash

Snowcrash works with intellectual property holders, brands, artists, generative art scientists, AR-XR-VR artists, interactive world builders, games world architects to create collections of master editions, limited editions, streaming rights, and digital goods over a broad category of digital assets in visual art, music, movies, sports, games, architecture, and collectibles.

The post Civic Partners With Snowcrash for NFTs by Sony Music Entertainment and Universal Music Group appeared first on Civic Technologies, Inc..

16:01 • 4 days ago

KuppingerCole

Where IAM trends are set: Everything around Identity & Privacy at EIC 2022

by Martin Kuppinger Anyone who has attended our European Identity & Cloud Conference (EIC) in the past 15 years will know that this is the leading event when it comes to current and future trends in  IAM and privacy (not to mention cloud security or cybersecurity). EIC is about the union of analyst thought leadership, the expertise of industry leaders, and best practices from the field.

by Martin Kuppinger

Anyone who has attended our European Identity & Cloud Conference (EIC) in the past 15 years will know that this is the leading event when it comes to current and future trends in  IAM and privacy (not to mention cloud security or cybersecurity). EIC is about the union of analyst thought leadership, the expertise of industry leaders, and best practices from the field.

This year‚Äôs EIC continues and strengthens this proud tradition with more than 200 speakers, covering a huge range of topics, which an increased focus on cybersecurity.

Some of the highlights in the ‚Äútrending topics‚Äù area include:

PAM (Privileged Access Management) redefined: With digital transformation and the shift to the cloud, increasing regulatory demands, and the growth of DevOps,  PAM offerings are evolving rapidly. We will have a look at this evolution. Getting a grip on entitlements in the cloud: Closely related to this is the emergence of CIEM (Cloud Infrastructure Entitlement Management) and the broader concept of DREAM (Dynamic Resource Entitlement and Access Management), the latter unveiled by us at last year‚Äôs EIC. Reinventing Identity and Access Governance: Role-based IAM projects tend to stall, and no one likes to do access recertifications. It‚Äôs time to rethink, and time for breakthrough innovations addressing the root causes of issues and not just the symptoms. The return of policy-based access management: While being the norm in authentication, we still have a long way to go for mainstream adoption of policy-based access in the authorization. There is also a lot going on in the market, and we will shed a light on this. The rise of decentralized identities: A well-established topic of EIC. We have been tracking and fostering evolution for years, and decentralized identities are now becoming a reality. Really passwordless: It is also not new that ‚Äúpasswords are dead‚Äù (and continue to exist). But passwordless authentication has become a real-world option now, not only for consumers but also for the workforce. How to get there? Visit EIC. Fraud, identity, security intelligence & UBA: Zero Trust champions the concept of ‚Äúalways verify‚Äù (instead of blindly trusting). Fraud reduction, user behavior analytics, and identity & security intelligence are all ways of mitigating access risks by not only looking at static entitlements but also at actual account behavior. AI for IAM: Finally, AI ‚Äì more as an ‚Äúaugmenting‚Äù than an ‚Äúartificial‚Äù intelligence ‚Äì in IAM and Cybersecurity will be an important theme. Again, there is a lot going on in the market, and EIC is the place to learn about the newest concepts, as well as to understand what is ready to be put into practice.

This year will finally be the year where we can gather again in a large group, while still engaging with all those joining this fully hybrid event remotely from around the world.

Book your place without further delay for this great opportunity to connect with vendors, industry thought leaders,  your peers, and the KuppingerCole analysts, either virtually online or in-person in Berlin.

*Avast set to acquire SecureKey, an identity and authentication provider that simplifies consumer access to online services and applications

*Google's plan to acquire Mandiant for $5.4B in an all-cash deal

Dock

Dock‚Äôs Strategic Hiring in the Engineering and Developer Field

The engineering and development team scaled their efforts to achieve our roadmap milestones. As such, Dock executed a strategic search for specialized talent in a development and engineering role.

After a successful launch of Dock‚Äôs Mobile Wallet App and the alpha launch of Dock Certs, the engineering and development team scaled their efforts to achieve our roadmap milestones. As such, Dock executed a strategic search for specialized talent in a development and engineering role.

We‚Äôre excited to announce two new joiners; Oleg Nosov as Senior Software Engineer and Osinakayah Ifeanyi as Fullstack Developer. With their help, the Dock team is able to work on and launch new features in the Dock product portfolio as well as plan and deliver the 2022 roadmap.

Both Oleg and Ossy play an important role in the Dock team with the expertise leading many features that will soon be released.

Over 2 months ago, Oleg connected with Dock as our Senior Software Engineer and went straight to work on automating the rewards payout after each staking era. Oleg‚Äôs focus within Dock is on blockchain engineering and inter-blockchain communication while remaining a contributor to many open-source Rust libraries and frameworks.

Being a part of the crypto world since 2016, Oleg worked as a Senior Software Engineer since 2018 and focused on the zero-knowledge proofs and related verifiable projects since the beginning of 2021. Previous work revolved around being a Senior Software Engineer in Matter Labs and a Technical Lead in an outsourcing company.

Shortly after Oleg‚Äôs appearance, Osinakaya Ifeanyi joined Dock as a Fullstack Developer. Ossy entered the crypto world 3 years ago being lured in by DeFi and GameFi. Previous work circled around being a Mobile Developer for a bank and then a Fullstack Developer for various SaaS products.

Continuing as a Fullstack Developer with Dock, Ossy went straight to work on Dock‚Äôs mobile app. Currently, the mobile app is centered around storing, sending, and receiving DOCK tokens. With Ossy‚Äôs expertise, Dock‚Äôs mobile app will allow users to accept and hold verifiable credentials on their mobile devices. A later version of the app will include the functionality to stake DOCK tokens.

The Dock team is growing at a fast pace and we‚Äôre excited to bring in new and well-needed talent to help Dock grow. We‚Äôre currently hiring for one last specialized role of Head of Business Development, read the full job specification and apply here. If you‚Äôd like to join the tight-knit team, follow us on social media and keep an eye out for future vacancies.

Explainer The Era of Self-Sovereign Identity ChakRay

Similar actions conducted in person do not represent the same amount of risk. For example, if someone asks you to verify your identity, we show our ID or driver‚Äôs license, and when you pay at the store, you provide your bank card. In this way, the control and the ownership of the data stays with you.

What role will public vs. private institutions play in the rollout of eIDAS 2.0 wallets? [‚Ä¶] The duo discusses the looming impact of eIDAS 2.0 on digital identity globally, how to keep data secure when verifying the identity of individuals and businesses online, and the European Union's clear vision for where digital identity is headed.

A Business Trip with FlexID SSID Kudzaishe George Zharare

In the offline world, we typically store credentials in a physical wallet ‚Äî it keeps them all in one place, protects them by keeping them close to our body, and makes them easy to carry around and access when we need them. The job of a digital wallet is no different:

Store your credentials, keys/keycards, bills/receipts, etc

Protect them from theft or prying eyes.

Keep them handy ‚Äî easily available and portable across all your devices.

Our online relationships are almost all transactional. A purely transaction digital life can't feel as rich and satisfying as one based on interactional relationships. As more of our relationships are intermediated by technology, finding ways to support interactional relationships will allow us to live authentic digital lives.

Technical Design and Development of SSI Management Platform Blockchain Healthcare Today

we leveraged the Hyperledger Indy blockchain framework to store patient‚Äôs decentralized identifiers (DIDs) and the schemas or format for each credential type. In contrast, the credentials containing patient data are stored ‚Äúoff-ledger‚Äù in each person‚Äôs wallet and accessible via a computer or smartphone. We used Hyperledger Aries as a middleware layer (API) to connect Hyperledger Indy with the front-end, which was developed using a JavaScript framework, ReactJS (Web Application) and React Native (iOS Application).

A credential is issued, and then held for a long period of time with intermittent voluntary presentations to many different verifiers.

#45 - Self-Sovereign Digital Identity, Blockchain & Web3 with Charlyn Ho I ALSO Want Money

Could blockchain and the decentralized web mean the end of surveillance capitalism? Maybe! In this episode, Perkins Coie partner Charlyn Ho defines digital identity, explains how blockchain empowers users to take control of their data, and shares how Web3 could dismantle Big Tech‚Äôs monopoly on Big Data - if it‚Äôs built the right way.

Own and verify your personal identity for web3 RealID Eth

1. With one line of code verify realid.eth wallet addresses.

const result = await provider.resolveName(`${address}.realid.eth`);      if(parseInt(address, 16) === parseInt(result, 16)) {  // address has Real ID }

2. Guard against Sybil attacks and follow KYC/AML regulations.
3. Reduce sign-up friction and lower costs for exchange.
4. If desired, create membership requirements based off of the attached identity (for instance, if you wanted to create an NFT collection that could only be minted by residents of New York City) without requiring users to give up their whole identity.

Web 3.0 and digital identity- (In Chinese) Fraser Edwards via Johnny Fry

Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) is arguably the most effective form of digital identity in Web 3.0. SSI is a user-centric identification method for controlling information. Fully aligned with Web 3.0, SSI eliminates the need to store personal information entirely on a central database and gives individuals greater control over the information they share to protect their privacy.

The future of Decentralized Identity: SSI vs NFTs Walt ID

While SSI has been developed to model digital identity, NFTs are used to model digital ownership. As a result, the concepts and technologies on which each approach is based differ with far reaching consequences. For example, while NFTs require blockchains, SSI can be used with or without them which is particularly important in the context of compliance and privacy.

Web 3 Meta Beyond the Metaverse Hype Heather Vescent

thoughtful -nfo

On March 11, 2022, I was a panelist on The Metaverse: The Emperor‚Äôs New Clothes panel at the Vancouver International Privacy & Security Summit‚Äôs panel. Nik Badminton set the scene and led a discussion with myself, James Hursthouse and Kharis O‚ÄôConnell.
[‚Ä¶]
Appreciate the past. I‚Äôm worried too much knowledge about how we‚Äôve done things in the past is being lost. But not everything needs to go into the future. Identify what has worked and keep doing it. Identify what hasn‚Äôt worked and iterate to improve on it.

Are blockchain-based DAOs really a utopian revolution in the making? John Naughton - The Guardian

DAOs are, I think, one of the best illustrations of the problem with a lot of these Web3 projects: They are trying to find technological solutions that will somehow codify very complex social structures.

Identity not SSI ‚Äã‚ÄãCloudflare‚Äôs investigation of the January 2022 Okta compromise

Our understanding is that during January 2022, hackers outside Okta had access to an Okta support employee‚Äôs account and were able to take actions as if they were that employee. In a screenshot shared on social media, a Cloudflare employee‚Äôs email address was visible, along with a popup indicating the hacker was posing as an Okta employee and could have initiated a password reset.

OpenID Foundation Publishes Whitepaper on Open Banking

The OpenID Foundation is pleased to share its new whitepaper, ‚ÄúOpen Banking, Open Data and Financial-Grade APIs‚Äù. The paper documents the international movement towards Open Banking, Open Finance, and secure, consent driven access to all user data. It describes the OpenID Foundation and in particular the Financial-Grade API (FAPI) Working Group‚Äôs experience with Open Banking ecosystems internationally.
